docs.abstract: Appearing before cameras sometimes multiple times a day to talk about the outbreak, the president has offered rosy assessments and unproven or even false assertions.
docs.snippet: Appearing before cameras sometimes multiple times a day to talk about the outbreak, the president has offered rosy assessments and unproven or even false assertions.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a campaign rally this week in North Carolina, President Trump reassured the crowd that he had jawboned the nation’s pharmaceutical companies into quickly tackling the coronavirus.

headline.main: Trump Makes Room for Experts, but Still Takes a Leading Role on Coronavirus
headline.print_headline: Health Experts Try to Rein In Trump’s Medical Bluster

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

byline.original: By Peter Baker and Michael Crowley

docs.abstract: The administration, citing the coronavirus threat to detention facilities, plans to turn back all undocumented immigrants and asylum seekers to Mexico.
docs.snippet: The administration, citing the coronavirus threat to detention facilities, plans to turn back all undocumented immigrants and asylum seekers to Mexico.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration plans to immediately turn back all asylum seekers and other foreigners trying to cross the southwestern border illegally, saying they cannot risk allowing the coronavirus to spread through detention facilities and among Border Patrol agents, four administration officials said on Tuesday.

headline.main: Citing Coronavirus, Trump Will Announce Strict New Border Controls
headline.print_headline: Trump Prepares to Tighten Border With Mexico

byline.original: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

docs.abstract: The president tried to rewrite his history with advising Americans about the coronavirus. His own words prove him wrong.
docs.snippet: The president tried to rewrite his history with advising Americans about the coronavirus. His own words prove him wrong.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, President Trump has minimized the coronavirus, mocked concern about it and treated the risk from it cavalierly. On Tuesday he took to the White House lectern and made a remarkable assertion: He knew it was a pandemic all along.

headline.main: Trump Now Claims He Always Knew the Coronavirus Would Be a Pandemic
headline.print_headline: Saying He Long Saw Pandemic, Trump Rewrites History

docs.abstract: The spread of the coronavirus is shutting down school systems across the country, but the federal government is offering little clarity on when they can reopen and what they should offer meanwhile.
docs.snippet: The spread of the coronavirus is shutting down school systems across the country, but the federal government is offering little clarity on when they can reopen and what they should offer meanwhile.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With their doors closed, their reopening dates in flux and their promised “distance learning” offerings in doubt, the nation’s school administrators are pleading with the federal government for guidance to respond to the worsening coronavirus outbreak.

headline.main: As Schools Look for Guidance, Educators Are Left Asking, ‘What?’
headline.print_headline: Schools Want Guidance, But Confusion Reigns

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

docs.abstract: Bail out groups of companies? Help local governments? The United States is laser-focused on what might come next from its central bank.
docs.snippet: Bail out groups of companies? Help local governments? The United States is laser-focused on what might come next from its central bank.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over a frenetic two weeks, as the coronavirus has upended American capitalism and changed every aspect of life, the Federal Reserve has taken drastic steps to keep money flowing throughout the financial system.

headline.main: Fed Faces Pressure to Do More as Virus Demands a Response
headline.print_headline: Fast-Moving Crisis Puts Pressure on the Fed for a Rapid Response

byline.original: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

docs.abstract: By nominating John Ratcliffe for director of national intelligence, President Trump gave the Senate a choice: Accept a Trump stalwart or stick with the acting stalwart.
docs.snippet: By nominating John Ratcliffe for director of national intelligence, President Trump gave the Senate a choice: Accept a Trump stalwart or stick with the acting stalwart.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The legal career of Representative John Ratcliffe, Republican of Texas, almost ended before it began. As a teenager, the future federal prosecutor confused “reverse” and “drive” on a borrowed stick-shift car and plowed through the window of a hearing-aid shop in Carbondale, Ill., where the proprietor had to yank an older customer to safety.

headline.main: With Intelligence Nominee, Trump Ensures an Ally Will Have the Post
headline.print_headline: With Intelligence Nominee, Trump Ensures an Ally Will Have the Post

byline.original: By Elizabeth Williamson and Julian E. Barnes

docs.abstract: The State Department also said that citizens abroad should either return home or stay in place. Some Americans overseas have urged the Trump administration to evacuate them.
docs.snippet: The State Department also said that citizens abroad should either return home or stay in place. Some Americans overseas have urged the Trump administration to evacuate them.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department announced on Thursday that Americans should not travel outside the country, and that citizens abroad should either return home or stay in place as the coronavirus pandemic grows.

headline.main: As Pandemic Grows, U.S. Warns Americans Not to Travel Abroad
headline.print_headline: U.S. Strengthens Its Warning on Travel

docs.abstract: Republicans sought to put their imprint on an emerging economic stabilization package of $1 trillion, unveiling a bill that includes tax cuts and loans to businesses and would curtail paid leave.
docs.snippet: Republicans sought to put their imprint on an emerging economic stabilization package of $1 trillion, unveiling a bill that includes tax cuts and loans to businesses and would curtail paid leave.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House and lawmakers scrambled on Thursday to flesh out details of a $1 trillion economic stabilization plan to help workers and businesses weather a potentially deep recession, negotiating over the size and scope of direct payments to millions of people and aid for companies facing devastation in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline.main: Senate Rescue Package Includes Corporate Tax Cuts and $1,200 Checks
headline.print_headline: Senate Rescue Bill Includes Corporate Tax Cuts and $1,200 Checks

byline.original: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

docs.abstract: The move was the latest reshuffling of top intelligence officials that has prompted concerns among some officials of a broader expulsion.
docs.snippet: The move was the latest reshuffling of top intelligence officials that has prompted concerns among some officials of a broader expulsion.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials with the Trump administration abruptly replaced the acting head of the National Counterterrorism Center this week amid planned cutbacks by the acting director of national intelligence, Richard Grenell, that have prompted fears among career officials of potential political retribution and a widespread loss of expertise.

headline.main: Counterterrorism Chief Exits as Top U.S. Intelligence Official Weighs Cuts
headline.print_headline: Acting Chief Is Leaving Counterterrorism Center

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Office of the Director of National Intelligence

byline.original: By Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt

docs.abstract: The reversal, which followed a bipartisan backlash, will last for only a year unless Congress permanently changes the program’s eligibility requirements.
docs.snippet: The reversal, which followed a bipartisan backlash, will last for only a year unless Congress permanently changes the program’s eligibility requirements.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing a bipartisan backlash led by Republican lawmakers, the Trump administration is backing off a bookkeeping change that would have drastically cut federal funds for rural schools — at least for a year.

headline.main: Education Dept. Reverses Plan to Cut Rural School Funding
